I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
facility  of  up  to  $200  million  without  government  guarantee  comprising  (i)  a  loan  to  China 
Everbright  Biomass  Energy  Investment  Limited  (CEBEIL)  of up  to  $120 million,  of  which  up  to 
$60 million (A loan) will be funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and up to $60 million 
(B  loan)  will  be  funded  by  international  commercial  banks  under  a  participation  agreement 
between ADB and such banks; and (ii) a loan to China Everbright Environmental Energy Limited 
(CEEEL) of up to $80 million, of which up to $40 million (A loan) will be funded by ADB and up 
to  $40  million  (B  loan)  will  be  funded  by  international  commercial  banks  under  a  participation 
agreement  between  ADB  and  such  banks, for  the  Agricultural  and  Municipal Waste to  Energy 
Project in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

2. 
The  PRC  faces  a  serious  environmental  and  social  challenge  in  dealing  with  waste, 
which  has  been  rapidly  increasing  as  a  consequence  of  the  country's  economic  growth. 
Uncontrolled disposal of untreated waste is widespread in urban and rural areas, even though it 
can  contaminate  soil  and  groundwater.  In  urban  areas,  untreated  waste  can  find  its  way  into 
drinking water and put its safety at risk, which will expose the population at large, but especially 
the  urban  poor,  to  infectious  diseases  and  other  health  problems.  Inadequately  treated  waste 
will threaten food production and security in rural areas, as nutrients contained in straw cannot 
be recycled into the fields without proper treatment. Even if burned, direct incineration of straw 
in the fields has a thermal impact on the soil, leading to deterioration of organic matter and loss 
of moisture. Uncontrolled direct incineration of agricultural waste can also generate fumes and 
fly ash, which have become a major source of environmental pollution and respiratory diseases. 
 
The PRC is the world’s biggest generator of agricultural waste,1 with an average growth 
3. 
of 5%–10% annually. According to the Government of the PRC, the total yield of crop straw in 
2010  reached  over  700  million  tons.  However,  about  45%  of  the  straw  was  directly  burned  or 
abandoned  in  2010  due  to  lack  of  technology,  funding,  and  awareness  of  local  farmers.  The 
PRC is also the world’s second largest generator of municipal solid waste (MSW)2
 due to rapid 
economic growth and urbanization.  MSW was estimated to reach 221 million tons annually by 
the  end  of  2010.  In  2010,  36.5%  of  total  MSW  collected  was  untreated.  Therefore,  improving 
waste management in the PRC is an important and urgent task. 
 
The  common goal  of agricultural  waste  and  MSW management  is to  treat the  waste  in 
4. 
an environmentally and socially acceptable manner with appropriate clean technologies. ADB’s 
public  sector  operations  have  been  supporting  broad-based  policy  and  regulatory  reforms  for 
efficient  agricultural  waste  management  since  19943 and  MSW  management  since  2000.4
 All 
waste  disposal  alternatives  eventually  decompose  organic  materials  into  simpler  carbon

 2             

molecules  such  as  carbon  dioxide  and/or  methane,  but  incineration  is  recognized  as  a 
particularly  effective  method  for  waste  treatment.  It  reduces  waste  volume  by  90%  and 
eliminates methane emissions, and waste-to-energy (WTE) technologies recover the waste heat 
from the incineration process and steadily produce electricity and heat. By replacing fossil fuel 
combustion and avoiding methane, WTE helps avoid greenhouse gas emissions and mitigates 
climate  change.  Therefore,  using  abundant  agricultural  waste  and  MSW  as  fuel  makes  WTE 
plants attractive and dependable sources of renewable energy. 
 
The  incineration  option  for  agricultural  waste  has  further  merits  as  it  yields  additional 
5. 
income to farmers who sell agricultural waste and also to small and medium-sized enterprises in 
charge  of  waste  collection  and  transportation.  In  addition,  the  treated  bottom  ash  could  be 
harnessed as an organic agricultural fertilizer for the domestic community. 
 
6. 
WTE for agricultural waste and MSW treatment is a very important and attractive option 
for the PRC since the government sets the development of a recycling economy as a national 
goal  and  promotes  renewable  energy.  ADB  has  undertaken  a  study5
 which  showed  that  the 
PRC  could  readily  utilize  crop  straw  for  electricity  generation,  through  direct  combustion  in 
particular.  To  mitigate  environmental  degradation  and  produce  cleaner  electricity, 
the 
government  aims  to  install  agricultural  WTE  capacity  of  up  to  24 gigawatts  (GW),  almost  four 
times  the  current  capacity,  which  represents  less  than  1.0%  of  the  total  energy  mix  and 
consumes  2.5%  of  the  total  available  agricultural  waste.  The  government  has further  issued a 
series  of  policies  and  regulations  to  support  agricultural  WTE:  (i)  full  offtake  of  electricity 
generated by biomass plants, including WTE plants; (ii) national targets by 2020 including 15% 
of  the  total  energy  to  be  generated  from  renewable  energy  sources  and  biomass  capacity  to 
reach 30 GW; (iii) value-added tax refund; (iv) exclusivity of agricultural WTE plants by allowing 
only  one  plant  in  each  county  or  within  a  100-kilometer  radius;  (v)  utilization  of  75%  of  total 
available straw by 2013 and 80% by 2015; and (vi) feed-in tariffs of CNY0.75 per kilowatt-hour 
(kWh) for agricultural WTE and CNY0.65/kWh for municipal WTE. 
 
7. 
Against  this  backdrop,  China  Everbright  International  Limited  (CEIL)  decided  to  extend 
its  operation  to  the  agricultural WTE  business.  CEIL  has  implemented  the  Municipal Waste  to 
Energy Project with ADB assistance since 2009, which supports the construction and operation 
through  public–private  partnerships  of  its  municipal  WTE  projects  with  advanced  clean 
technologies,  including  grate  incinerator  technology  and  advanced  flue  gas  emission  control.6
 
The ADB facility has been utilized for the development of CEIL’s clean municipal WTE plants in 
Jiangyin,  Jinan,  Suzhou,  and  Zhenjiang.  Considering  the  successful  implementation  of  the 
municipal WTE project, CEIL requested ADB to consider extending assistance to its agricultural 
waste  management  business,  as  it  plans  to  scale  up  the  business  given  the  vast  market 
opportunities  and  potential  development  impacts.  CEIL  has  also  requested  to  support  further 
expansion  of  its municipal WTE  project  into  new  municipalities  to  establish  a  solid  operational 
base from which penetration into the agricultural WTE market in the surrounding areas can be 
sought.  While  the  projects  are  of  homogeneous  nature  (i.e.,  same  technology,  same  raw 
material collection method, and same offtaker), local banks cannot finance these as a portfolio 
since  a  branch  cannot  operate  beyond  its  territory.  This  lending  limitation  results  in  fairly  high 
transaction costs.

2. 

Project Design 

8. 
Leveraging  the  successful  operation  of  the  municipal  WTE  projects,  CEIL  applies  its 
clean technologies to utilize agricultural waste to produce clean energy. The primary objective of 
the project is to support CEIL in extending its operations to agricultural WTE projects. In parallel, 
but to a lesser extent, municipal WTE projects will also be supported. Under the project, CEIL 
aims  to  develop  and  invest  in  agricultural  and  municipal  WTE  projects  to  treat  approximately 
7,300  tons  of  waste  daily  with  installed  capacity  of  210  megawatts  (MW)  to  generate 
approximately 1,240 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of electricity annually by 2016.  
 
9. 
Each plant incinerates waste, recovers waste heat for power generation, purifies waste 
gas,  and  disposes  ash.  CEIL’s  wholly  owned  subsidiaries,  CEBEIL  and  CEEEL,  will  hold  its 
agricultural and municipal WTE operations. To ensure that the focus of the project is agricultural 
WTE, 60% of the total assistance from ADB will be channeled to agricultural WTE, while support 
to municipal WTE will be limited at 40%. 
 
The ADB assistance is to provide a credit line to fund through the borrowers a series of 
10. 
WTE  projects  in  CEIL’s  investment  plan.  The  plan  includes  civil  works,  equipment  and 
materials,  other  procurement,  and  working  capital  for  9–12  WTE  projects  from  2012  to  2015. 
The ADB loan will play  a catalytic role to enable borrowing from the local banks at the project 
companies owned by the borrowers. 
 

3. 

The Borrowers and Sponsor 

The  project  is  sponsored  and  guaranteed  by  CEIL,  a  private  sector  company  listed  on 
11. 
the  Hong  Kong  Stock  Exchange  (stock  code  257).  Since  its  establishment  in  1993,  CEIL  has 
become  a  leading  company  in  environment  protection  business  in  the  PRC.  The  principal 
activities  of  CEIL  are  waste  management  projects  such  as  WTE  plants,  environmental  water 
projects such as wastewater treatment plants, alternative energy projects such as methane-to-
energy  power  plants  and  photovoltaic  energy  power  plants,  environmental  technology,  and 
construction management. In 2006, CEIL began commercial operation of its first municipal WTE 
project to implement advanced clean technologies. In 2010, CEIL entered the agricultural waste 
management business to leverage its clean municipal WTE technologies to agricultural waste. 
 
12. 
CEIL’s largest shareholder is the China Everbright Holdings Company Limited (CEHCL), 
a  company  established  in  Hong  Kong  that  holds  approximately  50.2%  of  CEIL’s  issued  share 
capital.  CEHCL  is,  in  turn,  owned  by  the  China  Everbright  Group.  CEIL  posted  revenues  of 
HK$3.67 billion ($472 million); earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization of 
HK$1.44 billion; and net profit of HK$845 million in 2011.  
 
The borrowers are both wholly owned and controlled by CEIL. CEBEIL, incorporated in 
13. 
Hong Kong, was set up to own agricultural WTE projects. CEEEL is incorporated in the British 
Virgin Islands, and is an investment platform to own all the municipal WTE projects.

B. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 

1. 

Impact 

Improvements  in  waste  management. The project will contribute to the improvement 
15. 
of both agricultural and municipal waste management in the PRC. Uncontrolled incineration of 
agricultural  waste  and  untreated  MSW  emit  harmful  gases  and  contaminate  soil  and 
groundwater.  The 
impact  of  demonstrating  and  deploying  clean  waste  management 
technologies  will  result  in  avoidance  or  mitigation  of  environmental  issues  in  both  rural  and 
urban areas. 
 
16. 
Increase  in  energy  generation  from  agricultural  and  municipal  waste. The  project 
features  a  strong  model  for  private  sector  participation  in  agricultural  WTE  through  a  public–
private  partnership  for  multiple  projects.  The  impact  of  catalyzing  private  sector  investment  in 
the PRC’s emerging biomass industry goes beyond the project’s specific interventions. Energy 
generation from agricultural and municipal WTE plants will result in reduction of greenhouse gas 
emissions by replacing electricity otherwise generated by coal-fired plants.  
 

2. 

Outcome 

The project’s outcome is increased production of energy from viable and environmentally 
17. 
sustainable WTE power plants in the PRC. The WTE plants to be supported under the project 
will ultimately generate 1,240 GWh of clean energy annually and reduction of greenhouse gas 
emission by approximately 638,000 tons per annum. 
 

3. 

Outputs 

18.  
 The  project’s  output  will  be  the  construction  of  at  least  nine  WTE  plants  with  an 
aggregate capacity of 210 MW.8 All the plants will be built in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy  Statement  (2009),  and  will  also  meet  the  new  national  emissions  standard  of  the  PRC, 
which took effect from January 2012.9

 which  defines  infrastructure  and

environment as two of the five core operational areas. On infrastructure, the project will embody 
the  strategy,  which  sets  forth  that  ADB  will  (i)  help  expand  the  supply  of  energy;  (ii)  promote

energy  efficiency  through  supply-side  and  demand-side  measures;  (iii)  support  clean  energy; 
and  (iv)  facilitate  the  removal  of  policy,  institutional,  regulatory,  technological,  and  legal 
constraints on promoting efficient energy use. With respect to the environment, the project is in 
line with the strategy's focus on climate change and complementary actions. 
 
ADB’s country partnership strategy (CPS) 11 for the PRC is based on three development 
20. 
pillars: (i) inclusive growth, (ii) environmentally sustainable growth, and (iii) regional cooperation 
and  integration.  The  drivers  of  change  are  (i)  knowledge  solution,  (ii)  private  sector 
development, (iii) good governance and capacity development, and (iv) gender equity. The CPS 
also sets out four priority sectors: (i) natural resources and agriculture, (ii) energy, (iii) transport, 
and (iv) urban development. The project will increase the production of energy from renewable 
biomass  sources  and  thus  contribute  to  the  CPS  objective  of  supporting  environmentally 
sustainable  growth  in  the  PRC.  The  project  also  complements  ADB’s  public  sector  assistance 
for efficient waste management, in particular the recent projects with biomass focus.12
  
 

2. 

Consistency with Sector Strategy 

The  project  is  consistent  with  ADB's  Energy  Policy. 13

 Under  the  policy,  ADB’s 
21. 
investments  will  focus  on  energy  efficiency  and  renewable  energy  projects,  as  well  as 
expansion of energy access. The policy states that support for renewable energy projects will be 
prioritized  and  broadened  with  an  objective  to  create  a  framework  that  makes  investing  in 
renewable  energy commercially  viable.  The  policy  envisages that,  in the process  of facilitating 
direct private sector investments in renewable energy, ADB will assume greater—but thoroughly 
assessed—risks  and  act  as  a  catalyst  for  investments  that  the  private  sector  might  not 
otherwise be willing to make. 
 
D. 

Project Cost and Financing Plan 

CEIL’s investment plan indicates a total investment of $656 million to treat approximately 
22. 
7,300  tons  of  waste  daily  with  installed  capacity  of  210  MW  to  generate  about  1,240 GWh  of 
electricity annually by 2018. The plan includes civil works, equipment and materials, other local 
procurement, and working capital for WTE projects between 2012 and 2015. 
 
23. 
ADB will provide a credit line that consists of A loans of up to $100 million and B loans of 
up  to  $100  million.  Proceeds  from  the  ADB  facility  will  be  channeled  to  project  companies 
controlled  by  CEIL’s  two  wholly  owned  subsidiaries,  CEBEIL  and  CEEEL,  as  a  part  of  their 
investment to mobilize local currency loans from local banks.

For agricultural WTE projects, each project company will obtain various 
authorizations for the development and construction of the project, including land 
use right and verifications by the National Energy Administration and the National 
Development and Reform Commission. The project company will also enter into an 
investment agreement with the respective municipal government. 
For municipal WTE projects, each project company will be awarded a concession,

government. 
Both agricultural WTE and municipal WTE projects will be supervised and

October 2012–October 2015 

Goods and services will be required to be procured in a transparent manner, 
through local competitive bidding procedures in accordance with CEIL’s 
procurement guidelines. Each project company will enter into engineering, 
procurement, and construction contracts with subcontractors. CEIL usually adopts 
a progress payment arrangement with the subcontractors, which have supported 
its strong track record by implementing existing projects in accordance with the 
schedule and sometimes even ahead of it. 

All project companies will sell electricity to the State Grid. A power purchase 
agreement will be executed between a project company and a local grid, owned by 
the State Grid, for the total annual generation. For agricultural WTE projects, a 
feed-in tariff of CNY0.75/kWh will be applied. Municipal WTE projects will enjoy a 
feed-in tariff of CNY0.65/kWh. 
For agricultural WTE projects, each project company will enter into fuel supply 
agreements with local partners and agricultural cooperatives. The fuel supply 
agreements will set out the specification of waste including size, water content, 
impurity, and minimum quantity, and the price. There are no fuel costs for 
municipal WTE projects, as a municipal government will guarantee fuel supply and 
pay a waste management fee to a project company.

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

ADB will provide A loans of up to $60 million to CEBEIL and $40 million to CEEEL. The 
26. 
A loans will be funded by ADB and supported by a full, irrevocable guarantee from CEIL. The 
proposed  loans  will  have  a  maturity  of  up  to  10  years,  including  a  3-year  grace  period  on 
principal repayments. Repayments will be in equal installments of principal.  
 
27. 
The B loans of up to $60 million to CEBEIL and $40 million to CEEEL will be funded by 
international commercial banks, have a maturity equal to or shorter than that of the A loans, and 
be on terms and conditions agreed by the borrowers, CEIL, participating banks, and ADB. 
 
[CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
B. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

28. 

The proposed transaction merits ADB’s assistance for the following reasons: 
(i) 

ADB US dollar loans are essential for the borrowers to invest in US dollar, as is 
often  required  by  municipal  governments,  and  will  also  serve  as  a  leverage  to 
mobilize  local  currency  financing  from  local  banks  that  are  unfamiliar  with  the 
sector and the technologies that the project will employ. 
The project structure will enable ADB to extend its reach to multiple agricultural 
and  municipal  WTE  projects  that  would  be  difficult  to  assist  directly,  while 
leveraging  the  experience  and  know-how  of  an  experienced  developer  and  its 
advanced technologies in municipal WTE and other sectors. 

(ii) 

 
C. 

Risks  

29. 
Fuel  (waste)  supply  risk. Availability of an adequate quantity and quality of waste will 
affect the performance of the WTE plants. Deterioration in waste quality can lead to less energy 
production.  An  increase in  the  agricultural  waste price  will  also  have  a  negative  impact  on the 
cash flow. With regard to the agricultural WTE plants, the risk will be mitigated by (i) diversifying 
fuel  suppliers,  and  (ii) by  monitoring  the  waste  quality  delivered  to  the  plant.  As  for  municipal 
WTE  plants,  this  risk  will  be  mitigated  by  guaranteed  daily  minimum  waste  supply  from  the 
relevant municipality in the concession agreement. 
 
30. 
Project sponsor credit risk. Debt service will be fully guaranteed by CEIL. This raises 
the issue of CEIL’s capacity to undertake such commitments. The credit analysis shows that the 
CEIL's financial performance is stable due to its contract-based, utility-like business that is not 
sensitive  to  economic  cycles,  and  has  geographic  diversity.  CEIL  has  achieved  stable  growth 
while  improving  its  balance  sheet.  The  credit  strengths  of  CEIL  include  (i)  strong  regulatory 
environment,  (ii)  stable  and  recurrent  revenues  under  long-term  contracts  with  creditworthy 
counterparts, (iii) sound term structure and sufficient liquidity, and (iv) top-tier market position. 
 
31. 
Completion risk. The project involves high initial capital expenditure for the construction 
of each WTE plant, making cost overrun and delay another potential risk. This risk is mitigated 
by  CEIL’s  strong  technical  expertise  and  efficient  cost-control  measures,  including  a  progress 
payment arrangement with the subcontractors. 
 

 8             

Electricity  tariff  risk.  Insufficient tariffs  could  adversely  affect  project  profitability.  This 
32. 
risk will be mitigated by strong government support which requires the grid utility to purchase all 
electricity generated by the qualified agricultural and municipal WTE plants, and pay them feed-
in  tariffs  of  CNY0.75/kWh  for  agricultural  WTE  plants  and  CNY0.65/kWh  for  municipal  WTE 
plants. While there  is  no  defined  tenor for these feed-in  tariffs,  a  CNY0.25/kWh  premium  over 
the benchmark tariff will still be applicable for 15 years from commercial operation in the worst 
case,  i.e.,  if  the  feed-in  tariffs  are  abolished.  As  for  the  offtaker,  the  State  Grid  is  a  large, 
established state-owned entity and the risk of payment default is considered low. 
 
33. 
Operation and maintenance risk. Operation and maintenance will be handled by each 
WTE project company’s staff, who will be transferred from CEIL or recruited from outside. This 
risk  will  be  mitigated  by  CEIL’s  strong  in-house  technical  and  management  expertise  and  its 
reliable track record in existing WTE plants. 
 
34. 
Foreign  exchange  fluctuation  risk.  This  risk  arises  from  currency  mismatches 
between the borrower's foreign debt service obligation and local currency receipts of the project 
companies. The risk will be partly mitigated by yuan-denominated loans from local banks. 
 
35. 
Structural  subordination  risk.  As  the  ADB  loans  will  be  extended  to  the  borrowers, 
CEIL’s  offshore  holding  companies,  and  not  directly  to  the  project  companies,  they  will  be 
structurally  subordinated  to  loans  provided  directly  to  the  project  companies.  This  risk  will  be 
mitigated  by  various  measures  which  are  based  on  the  measures  employed  under  ADB’s 
existing facility to CEEEL as well as other ADB projects with similar project structure.

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

36. 
The  project  is  classified  as  category  B  for  environment,  category  B  for  involuntary 
resettlement, and category C for indigenous peoples. The sites for CEIL’s municipal WTE plants 
are  selected  by  the  respective  municipal  governments,  and  to  minimize  impacts  on  the 
environment and communities. CEIL's agricultural WTE projects will be generally small in scale 
(30 MW or less) and will be in nonsensitive areas with abundant biomass supply. The municipal 
WTE projects have been voluntarily in compliance with the European Union 2000 standard for 
dioxin, which is 10 times more stringent than the PRC national standard, and this practice will 
continue  for  CEIL’s  new  municipal  WTE  projects.  Fly  ash  is  solidified  and  applies  cement 
stabilization technology before disposal in a landfill. Bottom ash is reused for various end-uses. 
Wastewater is treated on-site and is both reused and recycled. For its agricultural WTE projects, 
the company has adopted procedures and guidelines to manage potential impacts on air quality 
through the use of appropriate air emission-control equipment, and on water quality and quantity 
through  treatment,  recycling,  and  reuse.  Guidelines  also  govern  bottom  and  fly  ash 
management through recycling by supplying to the fertilizer and construction industry. 
 
37. 
CEIL’s  environmental  and  social  management  system  incorporates measures  to  avoid, 
minimize,  and  mitigate  the  potential  adverse  environmental  and  social  impacts  of  its  projects. 
The  audit  of  CEIL’s  implementation  of  its  environmental  and  social  management  system  is 
found  to  be  satisfactory.  CEIL’s  experience  with  its  existing  WTE  plants  ensures  that  the 
environmental  and  social  impacts  of  future  municipal  and  agricultural  WTE  plants  will  have 
adequate  mitigating  measures  and  monitoring  programs.  The  institutional  capacity  and 

 9 

commitment  of  CEIL  to  manage  the  project’s  social  and  environmental  impacts  are  deemed 
adequate.  To  ensure  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement,16
 the  borrowers  will 
be required to prepare an environmental assessment report and a resettlement planning report 
for each project and submit to ADB for review and approval, and implement the approved plans. 
The borrowers will also be required to submit annual monitoring reports. 
 
38. 
The borrowers will comply with ADB’s Social Protection Strategy and report regularly to 
ADB  on  their  compliance  (including  contractors)  with  national  labor  laws  and  adherence  to 
internationally recognized core labor standards.17
